headline: The Don Jr. Road Show in Ohio Was No Joke

Like so much of the party, Mr. Vance has changed his tune, now prostrating himself before Mr. Trump with as much zeal as anyone.

Even so, rolling into April, Mr. Vances campaign chest was light (despite the generosity of his former boss, the tech billionaire Peter Thiel), and polls showed him lagging other conservatives, including Mr. Mandel, who has made his own dash to the hard right in recent years.

Certainly, there is nothing the former president enjoys as much as watching a former adversary grovel, and Mr. Vance has been happy to gush about how wrong he was in 2016 and what a great president Mr. Trump turned out to be.
WEST CHESTER TOWNSHIP, OHIO  Its a chilly, drizzly evening, but Donald Trump Jr. is putting on a red-hot show at Loris Roadhouse, a bar and music joint in a strip mall on the outskirts of Cincinnati.
Best known as the author of Hillbilly Elegy,? his 2016 memoir widely embraced as a blue-staters guide to red-state values and grievances, his past was a bit too checkered for some conservatives.
Pretending to be a befuddled, senile President Biden, Don Jr. staggers around the low stage, eyes unfocused, making confused gestures and blundering into the giant red-white-and-blue backdrop.
The moment he got the much-coveted Trump tap on April 15, the election became about one thing only: whether the former president has the juice to propel an unexceptional candidate to victory.
One of the groups ads spotlighting Mr. Vances past attacks on Mr. Trump prompted the former president to have an aide fire off an obscene text to the groups president, David McIntosh.
Ohio is just the first test, the first time voters go to the polls in a race where the former president has put his political credibility and influence so solidly on the ballot.
Distinctly overshadowed, Mr. Vance is aware that, while his name may be on the yard signs and stickers spread around the bar, he is not who most folks have come to see.
Before the former president and Mr. Vance appeared together at a rally in central Ohio a week ago Saturday, Mr. Stovers group called on supporters to boycott the event.
Mr. Trump has said he chose to bless Mr. Vance because we have to pick somebody that can win.? Why he decided Mr. Vance is that somebody has prompted head scratching.
Tall and burly, with carefully manicured facial hair, the candidate has already done his quick opening act and faded into the background like a good sidekick.
He gazes attentively at the former presidents son, nodding appreciatively, clapping and grinning at all the appropriate (or, rather, inappropriate) moments.
The former president has a longstanding love affair with celebrities  and, perhaps better than anyone, grasps the value of celebrity in electoral politics.
